key_points: The author reflects on the death of their maternal grandmother, Anne, and former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, suggesting it's okay to not mourn certain individuals.
Anne died of coronavirus in Florida, and the author felt no need for eulogies, similar to their feelings towards Colin Powell.
Anne inflicted psychological and physical harm on her family, including using a dog leash on her children and biting her daughter.
The author's last contact with Anne was at age 11, after which Anne exhibited overzealous religious behavior and aggression towards family members.
The author was in Gjirokastër, Albania, when they received the news of Anne's death and felt no sadness.
Family members initiated commemorations for Anne on Facebook, which the author observed but did not participate in emotionally.
The author discusses the concept of grief, quoting Charles Darwin on the importance of strong affections in character.
The article questions the necessity of grieving for individuals who have caused harm during their lifetimes.
It suggests an honest reckoning with an individual's legacy, considering societal context, may provide better closure than traditional mourning.
The piece implies that it might sometimes be appropriate to simply say 'Good riddance' to the deceased who did not respect the living.
